title: BMC launches adult BCG vaccination campaign to combat TB - The Indian Express
summary:
BMC launches adult BCG vaccination campaign to combat TB

Publication Date: December 23, 2023

Source: Indian Express

The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) has introduced an adult Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccination drive aimed at addressing the tuberculosis (TB) crisis in Mumbai, which commenced on December 23 with 1,990 vaccinations administered across 12 wards.

  • The BCG vaccine has typically been given to newborns, but is now being offered to adults.
  • BMC Commissioner Bhushan Gagrani encourages eligible citizens to participate.
  • In 2023, Mumbai reported over 50,000 active TB cases.
  • The initiative is part of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme targeting TB eradication by 2025.
  • Vulnerable groups include those treated for TB in the past five years, household contacts, diabetics, smokers, malnourished individuals, and seniors aged 60 and above.
  • The Cy-TB test, introduced for early detection of latent TB, is cost-effective according to ICMR–NIRT studies.
“This initiative is a vital step in our fight against TB. I encourage every eligible citizen to contact their nearest health centre or TB programme staff and take advantage of this opportunity.” - Bhushan Gagrani, BMC Commissioner

In conclusion, the BMC's adult BCG vaccination campaign represents a proactive approach to combating tuberculosis in high-risk populations, supplementing ongoing health initiatives within the city.
newTitle: BMC launches adult BCG vaccination campaign to combat TB

title: Keto vs Paleo diet: Experts suggest which one to pick for guaranteed weight loss - The Times of India
summary:
Keto vs Paleo diet: Experts suggest which one to pick for guaranteed weight loss

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

As the New Year approaches, many are reconsidering their dietary choices, particularly the popular keto and paleo diets known for their weight loss benefits due to restrictive food intake.

  • The keto diet is a high-fat, low-carb diet that shifts the body's energy source from glucose to fat.
  • The paleo diet mimics the eating habits of early humans, focusing on whole, unprocessed foods while eliminating grains, dairy, and processed foods.
  • Both diets have shown short-term weight loss, but long-term sustainability and environmental impact are concerns.
“They’re terrible for the environment and fairly unsustainable.” - Federica Amati

Choosing between keto and paleo depends on individual health goals and dietary preferences, making it important to consult healthcare providers before committing to a strict diet.
newTitle: Keto vs Paleo diet: Experts suggest which one to pick for guaranteed weight loss

title: WHO looks back at 2024 - World Health Organization
summary:
WHO Looks Back at 2024

Published on: 23 December 2024 | Source: World Health Organization

2024 was a complex year for global health, with many highlights and breakthroughs. WHO reflects on significant accomplishments, challenges faced, and hopes for a healthier 2025.

  • Elimination of multiple neglected tropical diseases in seven countries including Brazil and Chad.
  • Egypt and Cabo Verde achieved malaria-free certification.
  • Record reductions in deaths from drowning worldwide.
  • Global tobacco use decreased, although youth usage remains a concern.
  • The launch of the first Global Report on the Commercial Determinants of Health scheduled for 2025.
  • Continued negotiations on a global pandemic agreement to improve international collaboration.
“We find ourselves in a time where fake news, lies, conspiracy theories, misinformation, and disinformation are rampant.” - Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

As WHO concludes another year of efforts, it thanks all partners and health workers for their unwavering support in achieving these victories and looks ahead to further advancements in public health.
newTitle: WHO Looks Back at 2024: A Year of Health Highlights and Achievements

Coffee, tea may protect against head & neck cancer: Study - Greater Kashmir
summary:
Coffee and Tea May Lower Risk of Head and Neck Cancer, Study Finds

Date: Dec 23, 2021
Source: Greater Kashmir

Consumption of coffee and tea can lower the risks of developing head and neck cancer, including cancers of the mouth and throat, according to a study published in the CANCER journal.

  • Drinking more than 4 cups of caffeinated coffee daily linked with 17% lower odds of head and neck cancer overall.
  • 3-4 cups of caffeinated coffee linked with 41% lower risk of having hypopharyngeal cancer.
  • Drinking decaffeinated coffee associated with 25% lower odds of oral cavity cancer.
  • Drinking tea linked with 29% lower odds of hypopharyngeal cancer.

“While there has been prior research on coffee and tea consumption and reduced risk of cancer, this study highlighted their varying effects with different sub-sites of head and neck cancer, including the observation that even decaffeinated coffee had some positive impact.”
— Yuan-Chin Amy Lee, senior author

Head and neck cancer is the seventh most common cancer worldwide, and rates are rising in low- and middle-income countries.
newTitle: Coffee and Tea May Lower Risk of Head and Neck Cancer, Study Finds

10 Beautiful Flowers That Kill Mosquitoes - Times Now
summary:
10 Beautiful Flowers That Kill Mosquitoes

Publication Date: Dec 23, 2024 Source: Times Now

This article explores a selection of attractive flowers that are effective in repelling mosquitoes, combining aesthetics with functionality in gardening.

  • Marigolds contain pyrethrum, a natural mosquito repellent.
  • Lavender's fragrance deters mosquitoes while adding beauty to gardens.
  • Citronella grass, known for its use in repellents, produces yellow flowers that repel mosquitoes.
  • Lemon balm has a strong scent that keeps mosquitoes at bay.
  • Basil has a strong aroma and is effective in mosquito deterrence.
  • Peppermint flowers are known for their strong minty scent that repels mosquitoes.
  • Bee balm attracts pollinators and repels mosquitoes with its fragrant oils.
  • Catnip contains nepetalactone, a compound that repels mosquitoes.
  • Tansy has strong aroma that helps discourage mosquitoes.
  • Geraniums, especially citronella varieties, have natural mosquito-repelling properties.

Harvard University shares 7 tips to keep your memory sharp at any age - Hindustan Times
summary:
7 Tips from Harvard University to Improve Memory at Any Age

Publication Date: December 20, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

As we age, keeping our memory sharp can become a challenge. Harvard University has provided seven tips to help individuals maintain and enhance their memory regardless of their age.

  • Keep Learning: Engaging in continuous education can help keep the brain active.
  • Use All Your Senses: Involve multiple senses during learning for better retention.
  • Believe in Yourself: Positive self-belief can aid memory improvement.
  • Economize Your Brain Use: Organize everyday items to avoid cluttering your memory.
  • Repeat What You Want to Know: Reinforce memory by repeating information aloud or in writing.
  • Space It Out: Use spaced repetition at intervals to enhance memory retention.
  • Make a Mnemonic: Use creative mnemonics to recall information more easily.
"Engaging the whole brain through varied learning strategies enhances memory retention." - Harvard University

In conclusion, by incorporating these simple yet effective tips, individuals of all ages can work towards maintaining and improving their memory function.
newTitle: 7 Tips from Harvard University to Improve Memory at Any Age

title: 5 Healthy Late-Night Snack Options - India Today
summary:
5 Healthy Late-Night Snack Options

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: India Today

This article presents five nutritious snack choices that are perfect for satisfying late-night hunger without compromising health.

  • 1. Roasted Makhana (Fox Nuts): Low in calories and high in protein, lightly roasted with ghee and spices.
  • 2. Moong Dal Chilla: A thin pancake made from moong dal, nutritious and easy on the stomach.
  • 3. Paneer with Cucumber Slices: A refreshing snack that's both protein-rich and hydrating.
  • 4. Hummus with Carrot Sticks: Nutritious and satisfying, perfect for a protein boost.
  • 5. Steamed Sprouts Chaat: Light and filling, it supports digestion while providing essential nutrients.
This selection of snacks ensures you can enjoy a late-night bite while maintaining your health goals.

Choosing healthy snacks before bedtime can not only satisfy cravings but also contribute to overall wellness.

title: Flu virus remains infectious in refrigerated raw milk: Study - The Tribune India
What To Not Eat In Pregnancy? - India Today NE
summary:
What To Not Eat In Pregnancy?

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: India Today NE

Pregnancy comes with many dietary restrictions to ensure the health of both mother and baby. This article highlights several foods that should be avoided during pregnancy due to potential health risks.

  • Raw or undercooked seafood, eggs, and meat - These can carry harmful bacteria or parasites.
  • Unpasteurized dairy products - These can contain harmful bacteria like listeria.
  • High-mercury fish (e.g., shark, swordfish) - These can harm the baby's developing nervous system.
  • Raw sprouts (e.g., alfalfa, mung beans) - These can carry bacteria that cause food poisoning.
  • Deli meats and hot dogs - These can be contaminated with listeria, leading to severe infections.
“These foods pose significant risks to pregnant women and their babies.”

In conclusion, avoiding certain foods during pregnancy is crucial for the health and safety of both the mother and the child.
newTitle: What To Not Eat In Pregnancy?

title: India registers 'significant progress' in reducing malaria cases: WHO - MSN
Sub-Saharan Africa has highest diarrhoea-related death rate among children: Study - Down To Earth Magazine
summary:
Diarrhoea Death Rates Highest in Sub-Saharan Africa for Children, Study Reveals

Published on: 23 Dec 2024, 11:33 am

According to a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, sub-Saharan Africa has the highest mortality rates for children under five diagnosed with diarrhoeal diseases.

  • 151.9 deaths per 100,000 boys and 132.4 deaths per 100,000 girls in sub-Saharan Africa.
  • Globally, diarrhoea accounts for about 9% of deaths in children under five.
  • Estimated 1.17 million deaths globally due to diarrhoeal diseases in 2021, a 60.3% decrease since 1990.
  • Major risk factors include poor neonative conditions, unsafe water, and poor sanitation.
  • The study emphasizes the effectiveness of health measures such as oral rehydration therapy and improved sanitation.
“The removal of all evaluated diarrhoeal risk factors would reduce global DALYs from 59 million to 4.99 million among all ages combined.”

Overall, the study highlights the need for continued health interventions and increased adoption of WHO-recommended rotavirus vaccines to further reduce diarrhoeal disease impacts.
newTitle: Diarrhoea Death Rates Highest in Sub-Saharan Africa for Children, Study Reveals

8 Ways to Identify Fake Protein Powder, As Per Dietician - HerZindagi English
summary:
8 Ways to Identify Fake Protein Powder, As Per Dietician

Publication Date: Recent
Source: Herzindagi

Learn eight expert-approved ways to identify fake protein powder, from packaging checks to mixing tests. Ensure the authenticity of your protein supplements and protect your health.

  • Check for high-quality packaging free of errors.
  • Ensure the product’s seal is intact.
  • Verify the lot number and expiry date.
  • Be cautious of prices significantly lower than the market standard.
  • Perform a mixing test to check consistency.
  • Evaluate the taste and smell for authenticity.
  • Scan the barcode or QR code for verification.
  • Purchase from trusted sources or official dealers.
"Look for high-quality packaging with no spelling errors or poor printing." - Dt Priyanka Bandal

Authentic protein powders provide essential amino acids for muscle repair and overall health, making it crucial to ensure the product's legitimacy.
newTitle: 8 Ways to Identify Fake Protein Powder, As Per Dietician

title: Advanced therapies for retinal vascular diseases - Ophthalmology Times
summary:
Advanced Therapies for Retinal Vascular Diseases

Publication Date: Not specified; Source: Ophthalmology Times

A panel of retina specialists discussed highlights from a recent Ophthalmology Times Grand Rounds event, focusing on advanced therapies for retinal vascular diseases like AMD, DME, and CRVO. They emphasized therapy durability and treatment management.

  • Discussion included the use of faricimab for various retinal conditions.
  • Case 1 highlighted improved vision in AMD patients with faricimab treatment.
  • Case 2 demonstrated faricimab's superiority over ranibizumab in treating DME.
  • Case 3 showed positive outcomes with faricimab for persistent CRVO.
  • Case 4 indicated faricimab's effectiveness in neovascular AMD with PED.
“This patient had rapid resolution of fluid with treatment durability and a low number of treatments,” commented Dr. Lally.

The advancements in these therapies indicate a shift towards more effective treatments with less burden for patients suffering from retinal vascular diseases.
newTitle: Advanced Therapies for Retinal Vascular Diseases

AIIMS, Delhi developing low cost adaptive cellular therapy for treatment of multiple myeloma - The Hindu
summary:
AIIMS, Delhi developing low cost adaptive cellular therapy for treatment of multiple myeloma

Date: December 23, 2024 | Source: The Hindu

Doctors at AIIMS, Delhi are developing a low-cost antibody-based therapy for multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer. This innovative approach aims to make advanced CAR-T cell therapies more accessible and affordable in India.

  • The therapy targets B-cell maturation antigen (BCMA) to specifically eliminate multiple myeloma cells.
  • Animal trials have shown promising results, with plans for phase-1 human clinical trials on the horizon.
  • The goal is to significantly reduce the costs associated with existing CAR-T cell therapies.
“CAR-T cell therapies have changed the way we approach and treat cancer. Development of CAR-T cell therapy has been in a nascent state in India despite the rapid pace at which it is moving around the world.” - Dr. Mayank Singh

This development is significant as it seeks to provide a more viable treatment option for many patients in India, addressing both cost and accessibility challenges.
newTitle: AIIMS, Delhi Develops Affordable Treatment for Multiple Myeloma Using Adaptive Cellular Therapy

title: Doctors Share The Items They Always Bring On Trips To Stay Healthy - HuffPost
summary:
Doctors Share The Items They Always Bring On Trips To Stay Healthy

Date: October 2023 | Source: HuffPost

There's never a good time to get sick, especially while traveling. Medical professionals share vital items they carry to maintain health and comfort on trips.

  • Pack N95 respirator masks to reduce respiratory illness risk.
  • Travel with vitamin supplements like Emergen-C for immune support.
  • Use antibacterial soap sheets for hand hygiene.
  • Have disinfecting wipes to clean surfaces on the go.
  • Don't forget hand sanitizers to keep hands clean.
  • Bring a travel-friendly first aid kit for minor injuries.
  • Stay hydrated with a collapsible water bottle.
  • Wear comfortable shoes to prevent foot problems.
“Wearing comfortable and supportive shoes will help prevent common problems like shin splints and plantar fasciitis.” - Dr. Pollyanna Pitt

Travelers should prepare for potential illnesses by packing key health essentials, ensuring their trips remain enjoyable and safe.
newTitle: Doctors Share The Items They Always Bring On Trips To Stay Healthy
